Award.AwardTitle: EFRI-ODISSEI: Origami and Assembly Techniques for Human-Tissue-Engineering (OATH)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The overall research objective of this project is to create assembly- and origami-based techniques for the generation of fully three-dimensional living tissues that are structured like natural tissues and include effective vascular networks. To accomplish this goal, the research first uses two-dimensional directed assembly to selectively locate multiple cell types in their proper locations on two-dimensional scaffold structures. The scaffolds are then origami-folded to convert the two-dimensional cell assemblies into three-dimensional structures that replicate the structure of natural tissues. This research addresses the three limitations to tissue engineering - tissue quality, tissue quantity, and speed of production - that have stood in the way of generating tissues for medical therapies. The project will also create new K-12 teacher training materials on origami in mathematics; involve high school students and teachers directly in the research; enable research opportunities for undergraduates from a diversity of backgrounds; and engage with high school students and the public through museum and high school level mathematics outreach.

If successful, this project offers the potential to save lives through the creation of tissues rapidly and efficiently with an extremely high level of control over tissue structure. At present, the limited supply of donor organs leads to thousands of deaths every year. The improved engineering of human tissues has the potential to save lives directly, through the provision of transplants to supplement the supply of donor organs, as well as indirectly, by creating tissues for the screening of new medical therapies before human testing takes place. From an educational and societal perspective, the benefits include enhancement of grade school and high school mathematics education through wide distribution of teacher training materials; increased opportunities for public engagement with origami mathematics through museum exhibits; and broadened research engagement of high school students, undergraduates, and teachers, with a particular emphasis on those from underrepresented minority backgrounds or who serve predominantly underrepresented minority communities.

This research project is jointly supported by the National Science Foundation and the US Air Force Office of Scientific Research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Engineering human tissues can save lives by making more organs available for transplant or by screening new medical therapies before human testing takes place.  For engineered tissues to work well, they need to mimic the three-dimensional structures of the human body, and there needs to be a way to manufacture them quickly and in large quantities.  However, meeting these requirements has proved to be a challenge.  It is much harder to make three-dimensional structures than it is to make flat, two-dimensional structures, and the manufacturing processes can be complicated and time-consuming.  This research demonstrated a new way of creating artificial tissues with complex three-dimensional structures and functions through the use of origami.  Origami is the traditional art of paper folding; starting from a simple sheet of paper, it is possible to create a folded paper crane or other piece of folded three-dimensional origami art.  Similarly, in this research we used origami-based techniques as a shortcut for creating artificial tissues with complex, three-dimensional structure from simpler flat sheets. The origami-based approach was demonstrated by creating artificial liver tissues and showing that they are suitable for testing medications.  The artificial tissues that we made are a combination of (1) an external (non-biological) structure that controls flow of nutrients much like your blood vessels do and (2) two different types of cells that are located in targeted regions within the artificial tissue to mimic the body?s structure.  Experiments showed that the artificial liver tissues behave much like the liver does in your body and that they also respond similarly to medications. This research has the potential to make screening of medications quicker and more accurate or even to help doctors choose the medications that will best help each patient.

One key outcome of this research was the creation of a new architecture and manufacturing process for creating artificial liver tissues.  In this new process, two different materials are folded together to enable the artificial tissue to have the equivalent of blood flow as well as the liver?s fine-structured filtering capability.  A second key outcome was the creation of mathematical models and the application of artistic insights to guide the design of the artificial tissue structures. A third key outcome was the invention and demonstration of two automated folding machines for the manufacture of artificial tissues.  These outcomes all form important parts of the intellectual merit of the project. The central key outcome, however, was the successful demonstration that origami techniques can efficiently manufacture even very challenging artificial tissues such as artificial liver that accurately mimic the function of complex human organs. 

The final outcome of the project was its broader impact on education and extending participation in STEM fields.  Undergraduates from Northeastern University, San Jose State University, and MIT participated in the research during the school year; undergraduates at Northeastern University undertook a long-term class project based on the research; eight high school students, seven high school teachers, one community college professor, and four community college students participated in the research through a summer program; we created and distributed educational materials related to origami mathematics to K-12 teachers; and we created and ran outreach activities on origami microfluidics for middle school girls from the Boston community. Our outreach programs effectively reached diverse communities that are underrepresented in STEM, including veteran and community college students.
